author: gcolvin
content: I'm not quibbling on semantics here -- in the end it is the client teams who have to decide.  Nobody else can do it for them.  What was problematic here was the very short notice, (two weeks may have been too long, one day was surely not enough,) that the meeting was called to choose between options A and D,  not between A and nothing,  and that the specific consensus of the client teams was not clear.

author: sky.cactus
content: In ACD, was the decision made to "decide between A & D in the breakout" or was the decision made to "decide whether or not to include EOF in the breakout"?  I think this is an important distinction because I suspect many people would not bother to attend the former meeting (they don't care between A & D) while those same people may have attended the latter meeting.

author: sky.cactus
content: I haven't watched either recording, but the sentiment I have gotten from this chat has been that a lot of people seem to have thought that the breakout was to decide between 2 options, not to decide whether or not to include EOF.  I get the impression everyone thought EOF was going to go in because it was SFId, and it was only "minor details of what exactly that meant" that would be decided in the breakout.

author: pcaversaccio
content: I have a question re the EIP-2935 contract https://etherscan.io/address/0x0000F90827F1C53a10cb7A02335B175320002935 - https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-2935#block-processing states that "At the start of processing any block where this EIP is active"; how can I see this `set` call in a block on eg Etherscan?

author: pcaversaccio
content: There are no recorded txs from https://etherscan.io/address/0xfffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffe - what I'm trying to verify for a block is that the history storage is properly updated.

author: sanleo
content:
I do not think you can, etherscan/explorers would only index calls that are made in the frame of a transaction. The set "call" isn't a transaction.
And its worth noting the "call" you're discussing is just a convention, clients may not make the call at all and just write to storage for example.

author: pcaversaccio
content: hmm, but the state change is part of the block correct?

author: pcaversaccio
content: what I'm trying to understand is how to verify this state change properly with a block data

author: sanleo
content: As far as I'm aware, but I don't think Ethereum indexes whole block state transitions, just per transaction for viewing purposes

author: pcaversaccio
content: well they also index withdrawals for example

author: pcaversaccio
content: btw the same question re: https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-4788#block-processing

author: sanleo
content: Sure but thats a special case thats useful for users. I don't think they would have bothered with a very esoteric case like this, its not necessary for any end user to view.

author: pcaversaccio
content: let's say I do `cast block --rpc-url https://eth.llamarpc.com`; I can't verify this state change based on the returned data, correct?

author: sanleo
content: I don't think so, no

author: pcaversaccio
content: hmm - and why is this the case? I should be able to verify all state changes based on the block data no?

author: pcaversaccio
content: same for EIP-4788 btw

author: sanleo
content:
Because it doesn't need verification -- its simply a rule all clients apply prior to the block
You could check via the state root, if that helps?

author: g11tech
content: etherscan wouldn't be able to provide as there is no explicit system tx thats doing it

author: g11tech
content: you can however call the contract and read from it (for 4788 as well)

author: pcaversaccio
content:
> At the start of processing any block where this EIP is active (ie. before processing any transactions), call to `HISTORY_STORAGE_ADDRESS` as `SYSTEM_ADDRESS` with the 32-byte input of `block.parent.hash`, a gas limit of `30_000_000`, and `0` value.
so why do you set a gas limit and value if this is not a transaction...

author: sanleo
content:
I think it was a convention set in place for future code upgrades at that address?
Just simplifies things from a client devs perspective, I'd guess.

author: g11tech
content: this is an internal call for `set`, you/clients can just  do evm call to contract, or directly modify the contract state as its easily mappable

author: g11tech
content: but there is no `tx` or logs for etherscan to index/detect

author: pcaversaccio

author: pcaversaccio
content: like sure, I can check the code

author: g11tech
content: you can probably do eth_call to contract and read data from it

author: g11tech
content: because why should the block carry inherent system tx making it more bulky and inefficient
